These ground squirrels are known for their social behavior, often living in large colonies and maintaining intricate burrow systems.

Spermophilus dauricus is primarily herbivorous, feeding on a variety of grasses, seeds, and other plant matter. They exhibit a distinct hibernation pattern, spending several months of the year in a state of torpor, during which their body temperature and metabolic rate are significantly reduced.

These ground squirrels play an important role in the ecosystems they inhabit, serving as a food source for various predators and contributing to the overall biodiversity of the region. Their burrowing activities also help to aerate the soil and promote the growth of vegetation.

Overall, the Daurian ground squirrel is an adaptable and well-studied species that provides insights into the ecology and evolutionary adaptations of small mammalian species in the harsh environments of Central Asia.
